section.title: Write-back Caching
section.para:
Write-back caching means that as I/O from the virtual guest happens it is reported as complete as soon as the data is in the virtual hosts page cache
QEMU User Docs: -drive options -
I remember the phrase write-back by thinking of it like this: As soon as a write happens on the guest a response is sent back to indicate that the operation has completeted.

Using write-back caching will have several side-affects:
PRO: Increased performance
Both the guest and host will experience increased I/O performance due to the lazy nature of cache-writes.
CON: Increased risk of corruption
Until the data is flush'd there is an increased risk of data corruption/loss due to the volatile properties of system cache.
CON: Doesn't support guest migrations
You can not use the guest migration hypervisor feature if you are using write-back cache mode.
CON: Not supported by all Operating Systems
Not all OSs may support write-back cache. For example, RHEL releases prior to 5.6
.
In reality, write-back is not as dangerous as it may appear to be, though the CONs out-number the PROs. The QEMU User Documentation says the following:

blockquote.para: By default, the cache=writeback mode is used. It will report data writes as completed as soon as the data is present in the host page cache. This is safe as long as your guest OS makes sure to correctly flush disk caches where needed. If your guest OS does not handle volatile disk write caches correctly and your host crashes or loses power, then the guest may experience data corruption.

section.para: If your guest is ineligable for the none mode, because it doesn't manage its disk write cache well, then write-back mode is a great secondary option.
